title: Directed Study
description: Individual study of selected advanced topics in electrical engineering and computer science. May include experimental work or reading. Primarily for graduate students. To be graded on satisfactory/unsatisfactory basis ONLY.
subject: EECS
advisory_prerequisites: Prior arrangement with instructor.
repeatability: May be repeated for credit.

title: Writing for Campus and Career
description: ELI 122 Writing for Campus and Career is designed to help you develop your writing skills for success in both academic and professional contexts. We will analyze and write a range of academic and professional written genres that you may be expected to produce both on and off-campus. Types of texts examined include statements of purpose, high-stakes emails, personal bio statements, and different types of essays. Assignments feature both individual and collaborative writing.
subject: ELI
repeatability: May not be repeated for credit.

title: Interactive Communication
description: This course is designed to develop conversational fluency. We will explore and practice modes of communication that fluent, experienced speakers of English use in academic settings. Discussions in class and activities outside of class will develop interactive speaking and understand the cultural practices of language and communication in seminars, meetings with professors, collaboration with classmates, and other encounters with expert speakers of English in their coursework and in campus life.
subject: ELI
repeatability: May not be repeated for credit.

title: English Vocabulary for Speaking and Writing
description: Do you find that you sometimes lack the words to say exactly what you want to express? Do you wish to write in a more academic style? This course offers a unique interactive online approach to enhancing your written and spoken English vocabulary.
subject: ELI
repeatability: May not be repeated for credit.

title: Pronunciation I
description: This class will enhance your ability to make yourself understood, whether on campus or in the larger community. We’ll identify the features of pronunciation that can maximize your clarity, and will introduce ways to practice these features to make them more automatic.
subject: ELI
repeatability: May not be repeated for credit.

title: Community-Engaged Learning in ESL Teaching Contexts
description:
This course introduces students to the theories and practice of English language teaching in the context of the local community and provides them with hands-on teaching practice experiences in local service organizations. Participants explore the overall theme of “Language and Community" by building knowledge and awareness of ESL teaching and learning through readings discussing the ideologies around the teaching and learning of English as a second language in the United States.

Students assist in a local ESL classroom or tutoring program for 2-3 hours per week for a total of 25 hours during the academic term. Potential site placements include:
Family Learning Institute
English Language Institute
Latino academic tutoring organizations
Ann Arbor Public School ESL classroomsClass Format:The plan is to offer this course in person if conditions permit. If visa delays or travel restrictions prevent students from being in Ann Arbor for the fall, this plan will be revised to allow students to participate remotely.
subject: ELI
repeatability: May be elected three times for credit.

title: Community-Engaged Learning in ESL Teaching Contexts
description:

title: Individual Research and Study
description: Students pursue individual research on a wide variety of topics related to second language acquisition, teaching or learning. Research projects would be completed done under the supervision of ELI faculty, who should be consulted as to possible topics or ongoing projects in which students could participate.
subject: ELI
advisory_prerequisites: Permission of Instructor.
repeatability: May be repeated for a maximum of 4 credit(s).

title: Academic Writing and Literature
description: What comes into your mind when you hear the word “medieval”? Beyond the chivalric motifs of castles, knights, and damsels in distress, the Middle Ages can also evoke images of violence, the Crusades, and the idea of a “Dark Age.” To understand how the period has come to bear such a multiplicity of meaning, we have to go back to the source.  In this writing-intensive course, we will focus on creating complex, well-supported arguments. We will focus on the intersection between critical thinking and persuasive writing, using literary texts from and about the Middle Ages as our point of reference. We will examine (some of) the ways the people of the Middle Ages viewed themselves, and, by contrast, examine our own definitions of “medieval.”  Working closely with peers and the instructor,  we will develop our writing through workshops and extensive revision and editing. We will learn to read medievalisms (both in texts and in images/iconographies) through the context of their own period and to identify what purpose(s) they serve.
subject: ENGLISH
sub_title: - Reading & Writing About the Middle Ages
repeatability: May not be repeated for credit.

title: Academic Writing and Literature
description: In this section of English 124, we will examine literature through the lens of the arts (broadly conceived as painting, sculpture, photography, music, film, dance, design, websites, games, and other media and entertainment). In glimpsing into literature, we will analyze writing about art, or ekphrasis, interpreting the ways in which writers have portrayed visual images or representations of art in poetry and short stories from the past and present. We will also consider literature as an art form, one that can evoke qualities and reactions such as beauty, wonder, rapture, or sympathy – or their opposites; that can invite or inspire appreciation, interpretation, response, creation, and action. Expanding our conception of ‘texts’ to encompass cultural artifacts and media, we will interrogate the boundaries between literature and art. Throughout the course, we will treat writing as an art, a craft carefully developed through revision and reflection. Questions to investigate include: In what ways can we trace patterns or images in a text? In what ways can we glean insights into the deeper meanings of literary works through a close examination of language, motifs, symbols, and other devices? What is the larger significance of the texts we read and write?
subject: ENGLISH
repeatability: May not be repeated for credit.

title: Academic Writing and Literature
description: In his essay, Projective Verse , Charles Olsen called for poets to consider the “open field:” to see patterns and formal qualities of poetry as responsive, rather than conventional, and to envision the poem as a physical site of action, in which form and structure respond to the needs of the poet, subject, and audience. This section of English 124 will investigate the poem as a site of meaning-making and linguistic transformation, or what William Carlos Williams described as “a field of action.”  In this class, our weekly readings will include some representative works from a range of poets including Rilke, Walt Whitman, H.D., Jack Spicer, Robert Duncan, and Denise Levertov, and critical essays from a range of poetic scholars, including Stéphane Mallarmé, Federico Garcia Lorca, and Aimé Césaire, among others. Our intensive, semester-long investigation of open field poetics is intended as a space for you to engage with academic composing practices (reading, writing, revising, research, and so on) in ways that support scholarly curiosity and inquiry, as well as engagement with writing as a collaborative, experiential, and innovative process. Together, we will explore questions about language and poetry such as: What is the role of the poet? What are their responsibilities? What possibilities can poetry as a ‘site of action’ offer? What  is language (and what does it “do”?) How do we interpret texts, and what makes an interpretation meaningful?
subject: ENGLISH
repeatability: May not be repeated for credit.

title: Academic Writing and Literature
description: This writing course focuses on the creation of complex, analytic, well-supported arguments that matter in academic courses. Students work closely with their peers and the instructor to develop their written prose. Readings cover a variety of genres and academic disciplines, with a primary focus on literary texts.
subject: ENGLISH
repeatability: May not be repeated for credit.

title: Academic Writing and Literature
description: How do we read texts that are about the lives of others? How do we write about ourselves and why do we take on such projects? To begin to answer these questions, we will read, discuss, and write about autobiographical texts. We will consider questions of self-representation, asking how authors choose to represent themselves and to what ends. We will engage with questions of identity, and what we mean when we use that word. We will think deeply about the relationship between an individual and a community, an individual and family, and an individual and history. Topics of discussion will include, but are not limited to, matters of race, gender, sexuality, social media, influencers, narrative, and myth. Readings will include memoirs, personal essays, graphic memoir, and scholarly essays by Harriet Jacobs, Sui Sin Far, W.E.B. DuBois, Gloria Anzaldua, Audre Lorde, Toni Morrison, Alison Bechdel, and Cathy Park Hong. Students will have the opportunity to write their own autobiographical work, but it is not an expectation of this course. Rather, we will be focusing on the literary study of autobiography and what it means to write about autobiography in academic contexts.
subject: ENGLISH
repeatability: May not be repeated for credit.

title: Academic Writing and Literature
description: This writing class is geared towards students with a strong interest in literature and the humanities. The course draws its readings from canonical 19th- and 20th- century poetry, and its unifying themes from T.S. Eliot’s long poem The Waste Land (1922).  The Waste Land is a major work of Modernist literature, and a touchstone for twentieth- and twenty-first-century literature. But why this poem in particular? Because The Waste Land is like a puzzle. At first reading, it seems inscrutable, throwing one strange “fragment” after another at us readers, and asking us to piece it together, with only a few hints and clues to guide us. However, after closer reading, it opens up, revealing an intricate network of patterns with seemingly limitless depth. In the five brief sections of The Waste Land, Eliot responds to, references, and even cut-and-pastes from texts throughout the history of Western culture, and beyond. Eliot’s poem “speaks” to every other text we read this semester, and they, in turn, “speak” to it. And with its modern mythology of sickness, sacrifice, and renewal, The Waste Land speaks directly to our own troubled times.
subject: ENGLISH
repeatability: May not be repeated for credit.

title: Academic Writing and Literature
description: What makes some literature so addictive, and what makes addiction literature—fiction and non-fiction work about addiction and recovery from it—so compelling as a genre? What makes us want to read about a father grappling with his son’s addiction? What draws us more to stories of addiction than to recovery? And finally, what makes us "hooked" on literature in the first place, as literary critic Rita Felski puts it?
subject: ENGLISH
repeatability: May not be repeated for credit.

title: Academic Writing and Literature
description: “What is time anymore?!” “In these challenging times…” “The time of coronavirus…” The last two years have left many of us feeling temporally topsy-turvy. For this reason, this semester seems like a good moment to investigate our experience of time and the ways this experience is represented in literary fiction. Travelers leaping from one century to another, bewildered characters stuck in temporal loops, threatening and unpredictable clocks—in one way or another, writers working in a wide range of genres love messing with time. In this course, we’ll engage with texts from the nineteenth century to the present that feature weird encounters with time in order to examine how stories organize and try to make sense of temporal experiences. We’ll explore how writers use narratives of the past or future to negotiate the present and we’ll delve into the ways representations of power, agency, and identity are entwined with temporal ruptures, narrative loops, and feelings of being too late, too early, or out of step with the prevailing tempo.
subject: ENGLISH
repeatability: May not be repeated for credit.

description: This writing course focuses on the creation of complex, analytic, well-supported arguments that matter in academic courses. title: Academic Writing and Literature
description: Sports and professional athletic competitions are (and have been) an essential aspect of society and culture. Athletics are both a means to find individual expression and create social bonds. Sports are also a method of establishing and/or fighting against socio-cultural or political boundaries. Rivalries (UM vs OSU, Liverpool vs Man U, The Patriots vs … everyone, or All Blacks vs Springboks) often inform and shape not only the athletes’, but also the fans’ identities. Athletics are embroiled in doping scandals, questions of social justice or equity, economic debates, and controversies surrounding gender. Sports have become powerful rhetorical positions that structure the way we tell stories about ourselves and our society. In this Writing Seminar, we first read, watch, and analyze stories by and about athletes and the athletic industry. We will ask what sports have to do with economics, international policy, and much more. We will evaluate the role of the individual and the community; inequality and empowerment; argument and sentiment; history, and representation in relation to the sporting world. Using narratives, such as Among the Thugs, Once a Runner, or the recent Olympics, we will imagine social identity through other (racial, economic, or gendered) categories. How have sports offered narratives or tools to think through or about the Covid crisis? Why have sports become platforms to support, protest, or even reimagine our communities and identities during quarantine? Each of you will assign a sport or narrative for the class to consider, thus compiling a diverse repertoire of athletic positions. For the research project, students investigate an athletic or sport phenomenon within a community of their choice or relate athletics to outside issues.
subject: ENGLISH
repeatability: May not be repeated for credit.

title: Academic Writing and Literature
description: The title of this course is drawn from the rallying cry of American modernism, which understood creativity as a process of revision.  Retelling myths, translation, allusion, parody, and revision are all ways to re-approach and rewrite old stories and ideas—to “make them new.” We’ll use this theme to draw together writers from the 20th and 21st centuries who revise myths, ideas, and each other.  As we read, we’ll consider how their revisions helped them to grapple with pressing cultural and societal questions.
subject: ENGLISH
repeatability: May not be repeated for credit.

title: Academic Writing and Literature
description: This course investigates the visual imagination of a variety of literary texts under study. We’ll discuss how and to what effects these works convey visual information, and while doing so, we’ll consider each text as its own meditation on seeing. Concerns may include, but are definitely not limited to, the following: (in)visibility, color, light, photography, animation, museums, cultures of display, and ekphrasis (writing about art).
subject: ENGLISH
repeatability: May not be repeated for credit.

title: Academic Writing and Literature
description: “What is time anymore?!” “In these challenging times…” “The time of coronavirus…” The last two years have left many of us feeling temporally topsy-turvy. For this reason, this semester seems like a good moment to investigate our experience of time and the ways this experience is represented in literary fiction. Travelers leaping from one century to another, bewildered characters stuck in temporal loops, threatening and unpredictable clocks—in one way or another, writers working in a wide range of genres love messing with time. title: Academic Writing and Literature
description: Our class will survey the “castaway tale” as it appears in novels, short stories, plays, nonfiction, film and even New Yorker cartoons. We will trace the lineage of the castaway through connections to colonial ideology, piracy and the history of maritime travel and trade. The course spans from the late 17th and early 18th century to contemporary times, questioning why the castaway trope has acquired such staying power in the cultural and literary imagination. Our reading list is still in the works, but will include a few of the following texts: Robinson Crusoe (1719), The Female American (1767), The Isle of Pines (1668), Gulliver’s Travels (1726), The Island of Doctor Moreau (1896),The Mysterious Island (1875), Friday; or, The Other Island (1967), Lord of The Flies (1954), Concrete Island (1974), The Martian (2011). We will also engage with literary theory, especially postcolonial and ecocriticism.
subject: ENGLISH
repeatability: May not be repeated for credit.

title: Academic Writing and Literature
description: This writing course focuses on the creation of complex, analytic, well-supported arguments that matter in academic courses. In this particular section, we will develop the fundamental skills for academic writing through a sustained exploration of one particular genre: the hard-boiled detective story, which subordinates the mystery itself to the (usually violent) investigations of the main character. Emerging from the inexpensive pages of pulp magazines, this genre and its cynical pro(?)tagonists enjoyed such popularity that now a handful of its common images—cigarette smoke rising under a street lamp, a detective’s name etched onto a door, a fedora in the rain—can turn a scene into parody or homage. After reading texts by the most influential writers of these stories, including Carroll John Daly, Dashiell Hammett, and Raymond Chandler, we will turn toward more recent authors who deploy hard-boiled conventions in bold and innovative ways. We will explore how these later novels and short stories interrogate issues that the genre’s pioneers tend to treat uncritically and insensitively, such as race, class, and gender. This course will also examine how hard-boiled fiction has been adapted to other media, both at the height of the genre’s popularity and now.
subject: ENGLISH
repeatability: May not be repeated for credit.

title: Academic Writing and Literature
description: What can poetry, whose root poïesis means “to make, to do,”  do? What role does writing play in representing, interpreting, and even refashioning our world(s)? From Chaucer’s bawdy Wife of Bath to the visionary Julian of Norwich, biblical worlds to Arthurian lore, we will examine the roles written narrative plays in society — as entertainment, instruction, revelation, and constructor of identity (among other guises). With an understanding of historical moments seemingly distant from our own, we can interrogate where we find remnants of the past in the present — how might these experiences be vastly unfamiliar or hauntingly proximate to ours? Our exploration of earlier writers’ works will serve as a launching point for considerations of how we think critically about our world(s) and ideas, what our writing is capable of as forms of exposition and argumentation, and the complexities that abound in these analyses and expressions.
subject: ENGLISH
repeatability: May not be repeated for credit.

title: Academic Writing and Literature
description: The past few years have placed divisions—political, cultural, economic, racial, and more—at the forefront of our national consciousness. To be divided, though, requires imagining a larger whole that has fractured, and implies that smaller groups have formed from the pieces. In this class we will explore what it means to belong—or not—to a subgroup, or to the mainstream, the larger whole. How are these communities constructed and maintained? How does one come to be included, to assimilate, and even to police the boundaries of their group? And what about those at the margins, between groups, or with each foot in a different world? Together, we will explore how writers represent the struggle to belong, to find one’s place in the world, and how they make arguments—implicit and explicit—about inclusion and exclusion. We will learn to ask effective questions about a piece of writing, and to formulate arguments which not only take note of the complexities of a text but which make clear the importance of attending to and analyzing these details. This class will engage with a diverse body of work, including poetry, short stories, novels, and film; together we will have conversations about difficult topics including gender, race, immigration, and more. Some of the voices we may encounter include those of Gloria Anzaldúa, Franny Choi, John Clare, Eduardo Corral, Cathy Park Hong, Jhumpa Lahiri, Marilynne Robinson, Zadie Smith, and William Wordsworth.
subject: ENGLISH
repeatability: May not be repeated for credit.

title: Academic Writing and Literature
description: This class will look at first-person novels that utilize a focus on day-to-day interactions. Their hyperfixation on normal social interactions allows the reader to question and challenge what is considered normal in our contemporary culture. Instead of spectacularizing violence or treating abuses of power as discrete events, these novels portray power and control in the form of "slow violence"—the boring non-events that perpetuate systemic inequality. The primary genre we will look at is dystopian novels, specifically those that dwell in inaction, boredom, and emotional fatigue. We will also incorporate secondary readings on race, class, gender, and sexuality in order to build frameworks that help our understanding of the texts at hand.
subject: ENGLISH
repeatability: May not be repeated for credit.

title: Writing and Academic Inquiry
description: This writing course focuses on the creation of complex, analytic, well-supported arguments that matter in academic courses. You will work closely with me and your peers to form effective close reading habits, hone your critical thinking skills, and develop your written prose. In this iteration of ENGLISH 125, we will cultivate a set of strategies to think and write critically about the uses of fantasy in such diverse literary and cinematic works as Marie de France’s medieval lai Lanval, Elizabeth Bishop’s poetry, Hayao Miyazaki’s animation Spirited Away, and Guillermo del Toro’s dark fantasy film Pan’s Labyrinth.
subject: ENGLISH
repeatability: May not be repeated for credit.

title: Writing and Academic Inquiry
description: This class is about writing and academic inquiry. Effective arguments stem from well-formulated questions, and academic essays allow writers to gain deeper understanding of the questions that they are exploring.  In this course, students learn to create complex, analytic, well-supported arguments that matter in academic contexts. The course also hones students’ critical thinking and reading skills. Working closely with their peers and the instructor, students develop their essays through workshops and extensive revision and editing. Readings cover a variety of genres and often serve as models or prompts for assigned essays.
subject: ENGLISH
repeatability: May not be repeated for credit.

title: Writing and Academic Inquiry
description: Writing is hard. But writing is also rewarding, being one of the main ways to express ourselves and make our ideas and feelings understandable to others. In this course, we will critically and honestly interrogate the writing process by focusing on its difficulties and how to overcome them. In our readings, we will engage with a number of literary, scholarly, and personal texts which are all concerned with the question of how we write, and why it is so difficult to do so. Our assignments will redirect the labor of a final paper onto the writing process, through reflective essays, peer review, and open discussions about our struggles as writers which will culminate in a portfolio students submit at the end of the semester. By the end of this course, you will become a better writer, through attaining a better understanding of your own writing process and those of others.
subject: ENGLISH
repeatability: May not be repeated for credit.

title: Writing and Academic Inquiry
description: You may be familiar with the phrase “the whole is greater than the sum of its parts.” This captures the essence of emergence, which is present across the sciences. For example, in biology, the property of life emerges from structures like proteins, cells, and organs that are not necessarily “living.” Furthermore, the properties of proteins, cells, and organs each emerge from substructures that are less complex.
subject: ENGLISH
repeatability: May not be repeated for credit.

title: Writing and Academic Inquiry
description: What is it that fascinates us about celebrities? Why do we idolize, admire, and feel a sense of kinship with people we have only ever seen from after, watched on TV, or read about in magazines? In this course, we will explore the technologies by which a star is born. From portraiture to The Gram — from starring roles to tabloid exposés —most of us already consume (and even produce!) the kinds of texts that we will encounter. Studying these narratives may tell us little about the real person behind the image, but much about ourselves as a society: what we value, fear, and desire.
subject: ENGLISH
repeatability: May not be repeated for credit.

title: Writing and Academic Inquiry
description: Climate change is many things: observable, immense, intricate, and contested. This course lives at the nexus of these elements. We will read a variety of genres, from primary academic literature to film scripts, technical reports to short stories, that cut across rigorous scientific inquiry and lived human experience. Through our writing we will strive to develop a holistic understanding of climate change and appreciate the innumerable aspects of earth, life, and humanity that it influences. Working closely with your peers and instructor, you will hone skills in critical thinking, reading, and communicating with a clear purpose. We will write in descriptive, analytic, and comparative forms and learn how our work can be tailored for a variety of audiences.
subject: ENGLISH
repeatability: May not be repeated for credit.

repeatability: May not be repeated for credit.

title: Writing and Academic Inquiry
description: This class is about writing and academic inquiry. Effective arguments stem from well-formulated questions, and academic essays allow writers to gain deeper understanding of the questions that they are exploring.  In this course, students learn to create complex, analytic, well-supported arguments that matter in academic contexts. The course also hones students’ critical thinking and reading skills. Working closely with their peers and the instructor, students develop their essays through workshops and extensive revision and editing. Readings cover a variety of genres and often serve as models or prompts for assigned essays.
subject: ENGLISH
repeatability: May not be repeated for credit.

title: Writing and Academic Inquiry
description: This course lacks an explicit theme, partly to avoid too narrow an investigative focus, partly to prioritize instead a spirit of collaboration and community. You will learn how to advance compelling, complex arguments crafted in a spirit of exploration and inquiry. You will learn how to support your claims and assertions with well-chosen examples and explanations. You will learn to develop your own voice. You will learn to trust your own critical thinking and judgement as you ascertain the needs of the assignments and their audiences. And you will learn all of these things from one another, not just from your eager, knowledgeable, yet still so very imperfect instructor.
subject: ENGLISH
repeatability: May not be repeated for credit.

title: Writing and Academic Inquiry
description: In this inquiry-driven course, we will explore and trouble the various understandings of the concept of genius through reading, writing, and responding to different stories, essays, books, and films. For instance, we will discuss questions like, how is genius gendered? What constitutes a genius? How is genius culturally relative? To try and answer these questions, we will practice critical thinking and writing strategies such as invention, drafting, and revision. Through these processes, we will consider a myriad of possibilities and rhetorical strategies to employ in composition, expanding our communicative repertoire to make stylized arguments in a variety of contexts.
subject: ENGLISH
repeatability: May not be repeated for credit.

title: Writing and Academic Inquiry
description: Learning to craft effective arguments begins with asking important questions.  So this semester, we’ll focus on a question central to your time at Michigan: What’s college for?  In our readings, discussions, and essays, we’ll look at how students, teachers, and writers have answered that question across American history.  There are more ways to answer our driving question than there are people who have asked it, so we’ll see how the answer can vary with time, place, person, and institution.  By the end of the semester, you’ll have begun to formulate your own answer—and to understand a little better what your goals are for the next four years at Michigan and how you might be able to accomplish them.
subject: ENGLISH
repeatability: May not be repeated for credit.

title: Writing and Academic Inquiry
description: Our course title, "Everything Is in the Language We Use," takes its quoted text from contemporary Ogala Lakota poet Layli Long Soldier, who writes: “Everything is in the language we use.” In this course, we will listen to, pay attention to, and interrogate ideas about language. Throughout the term, we will examine language as power, language as ideology in the world, and the living language(s) of our own communities. It is my goal for this course that we not only grow as academic writers, but also as critical, conscientious listeners of our local and global communities. How does writing urge us to listen and pay attention to the worlds both within and around us? How can we use writing as a tool to further listen to, challenge, and expand our ideas — both within and beyond academia? In practicing writing, we also practice communication, reflection, context evaluation, and, hopefully, empathy (in addition to many other skills). Because of this, we’ll be examining and discussing “texts” and media from a variety of styles and sources, and I will also occasionally ask you to bring in examples from other classes, interests, and/or your personal lives. We will think about the power and production of language, and we will grow our understanding of language by participating in a community of readers.
subject: ENGLISH
repeatability: May not be repeated for credit.

title: Writing and Academic Inquiry
description: You know what real audiences don’t want to read? Five paragraph essays. You know what they do want to read? Work that’s surprising, intriguing, disturbing. Work that's weird, like an academic essay which somehow links British political slogans, beer ads, the TV show 24, and the (anti-)truth of racial stereotypes. Or an oddly earnest essay about the moral and cultural conflicts surrounding erotic Rick and Morty fanart. Or the story of Roxanne Gay’s surprise obsession with the Sweet Valley High books. (All of which are on the docket for this semester.) In other words, this is a class about how to be writers who reveal the innards of what’s weird about our world and ourselves.
subject: ENGLISH
repeatability: May not be repeated for credit.

title: Writing and Academic Inquiry
description: This writing course will examine the politics of memory and place. As a class, we will think critically about the construction of collective memory, especially as it includes acts of imagining and forgetting. Special focus will be given to the relationship between humans and their environment, engaging with practices of embodiment and place-making as situated within larger political contexts.
subject: ENGLISH
repeatability: May not be repeated for credit.

title: Writing and Academic Inquiry
description: This class is about writing and academic inquiry. Effective arguments stem from well-formulated questions, and academic essays allow writers to gain deeper understanding of the questions that they are exploring.  In this course, students learn to create complex, analytic, well-supported arguments that matter in academic contexts. The course also hones students’ critical thinking and reading skills. Working closely with their peers and the instructor, students develop their essays through workshops and extensive revision and editing. Readings cover a variety of genres and often serve as models or prompts for assigned essays.
subject: ENGLISH
repeatability: May not be repeated for credit.

title: Writing and Academic Inquiry
description: The theme for this section of ENG 125 is "Writerly Purpose in African American Fiction". In our exploration of the various rhetorical strategies and organizational structures that more advanced academic writers tend to use, we will concurrently explore the writings (both fictional and argumentative) of some of the most famous African American authors of the 20th century. By combining the writing skills-based course assignments with thematic course readings, students will consider three main questions:
subject: ENGLISH
repeatability: May not be repeated for credit.

title: Writing and Academic Inquiry
description: This is a first-year writing course focused on the relationship between ourselves, our communities, and our desires. In this class, we will learn and hone our skills around advocating for ourselves—how to make persuasive arguments about the things that are important to us. We will consider argumentation from multiple angles, thinking about how the structure and form of our arguments need to change based on who we’re trying to persuade. We will study fields and topics such as contemporary racial justice, science, and technology studies, disability justice, and intersectional feminism in order to understand how writers before us have advocated for themselves and on behalf of their communities. As an introductory course to self-advocacy, we will think expansively about how to use writing and argumentation to achieve desired ends, using a variety of methods and sources. As a first-year writing course, we will develop the basic critical writing skills that you will use throughout your time at the University of Michigan and beyond.
subject: ENGLISH
sub_title: - Writing Advocacy: Our Communities Our Selves
repeatability: May not be repeated for credit.

title: Writing and Academic Inquiry
description: This class is about writing and academic inquiry. Effective arguments stem from well-formulated questions, and academic essays allow writers to gain a deeper understanding of the questions that they are exploring.  In this course, you will learn to create complex, analytic, well-supported arguments that matter in academic contexts. The course will also hone your critical thinking and reading skills. Working closely with your peers and instructor, you will develop your essays through workshops and extensive revision and editing. The theme of this course will be "Things Matter." Objects are important.  We read with things, we write with things, we play with things, and we think with things. We describe ourselves by discussing the things we like and the things we own. But we rarely take the time to stop and think about those things. How were they designed? What can we learn from them? In this course we will be analyzing and writing about objects: objects as they appear in literature--both fiction and nonfiction--and as we come across them in our everyday lives.
subject: ENGLISH
repeatability: May not be repeated for credit.

title: Community-Engaged Writing
description: In this community-based-learning course, students will develop academic writing skills through community engagement.
subject: ENGLISH
repeatability: May not be repeated for credit.

title: Community-Engaged Writing
description: Community Engaged Writing serves as an introductory overview to writing for academic and non-academic communities in a stance of self-reflection, humility, and respectful listening.  Through collaboration with the Edward Ginsberg Center, the class will collaborate with a community partner and practice applied, community-engaged writing.
subject: ENGLISH
repeatability: May not be repeated for credit.

title: Community-Engaged Writing
description: Aside from its focus on community-engaged writing, this course currently lacks an explicit theme, partly to avoid too narrow an investigative focus, partly to prioritize instead a spirit of collaboration and togetherness. You will learn how to advance compelling, complex arguments crafted in a spirit of exploration and inquiry. You will learn how to support your claims and assertions with well-chosen examples and explanations. You will learn to develop your own voice. You will learn to trust your own critical thinking and judgment as you ascertain the needs of the assignments and their audiences. And you will learn all of these things from one another, not just from your eager, knowledgeable, yet still so very imperfect instructor.
subject: ENGLISH
repeatability: May not be repeated for credit.

title: Community-Engaged Writing
description: In this course, students will work closely with each other, the instructor, and a community partner to develop critical reading and writing skills. The course will consist of a combination of discussing reading assignments, writing formal essays, and community-based applied work.
subject: ENGLISH
repeatability: May not be repeated for credit.

title: First-Year Seminar on English Language and Literature
description: Many people spoke for – and against – woman’s right to vote in the United States. These speeches are terrific opportunities to understand how activists argue for an absolutely fundamental civil right. They also show us how even progressive activists sometimes rely on conservative ideas in their paths to social change. Let’s look together at the slippery boundaries between binaries such as inclusion and exclusion, progressive and conservative, and also seemingly self-evident identities like “woman,” “white,” “healthy,” and “middle-class.” Sure, these speeches led to the 19th Amendment. What else did these speeches do, and undo? We’ll connect to contemporary U.S. politics, and lots more in our every-day-worlds.
subject: ENGLISH
sub_title: - Rhetoric and Rights: What Else Did the 19th Amendment Do?
advisory_prerequisites: Enrollment restricted to first-year students, including those with sophomore standing.
repeatability: May not be repeated for credit.

title: First-Year Seminar on English Language and Literature
description: We are taught as children that writing, especially poetry-writing, is a form of personal expression and a route to personal discovery.  In the 1950s poem “Theme for English B,” by Langston Hughes, a teacher tells a student to “let” writing “come out of you -- / Then it will be true!” to which the student replies, “But is it that simple?” He has a point:  Have you ever sat down to write “creatively” and just felt like you were coming up with clichés that made you feel in fact unlike yourself, and more like everybody else, or discovered something you couldn’t own as yours? Maybe you felt, as the student in Hughes’ poem does, that rather than you expressing you, culture norms or history was writing you?
subject: ENGLISH
advisory_prerequisites: Enrollment restricted to first-year students, including those with sophomore standing.
repeatability: May not be repeated for credit.

title: First-Year Seminar on English Language and Literature
description: Some people consider “the meaning of life” and the sources of meaning in one’s life as age-old questions at the heart of a liberal arts education. Others view these topics as overly abstract, too earnest, trite, hokey. In this course, we will take these questions seriously but we won’t treat them as timeless: instead, we will view interest in the meaning and meaningfulness of life as a historical phenomenon, one that took off in the late-nineteenth century. We will look especially to British novels from this period to understand why this was the case, and to ask why the novel itself became a key site for thinking about meaning. How we’ll ask, is interpreting a novel like—or not like—finding meaning in real life?
subject: ENGLISH
sub_title: - Literature and the Meaning of Life
advisory_prerequisites: Enrollment restricted to first-year students, including those with sophomore standing.
repeatability: May not be repeated for credit.

title: First-Year Seminar on English Language and Literature
description: In this first-year seminar, we both study and engage in the shared human practice of examining and making sense of one’s life and expressing and communicating life stories, in a wide range of mediums and genres. We will investigate a selection of Middle Eastern life narratives, ranging from more traditional life story genres like written memoir and autobiography, to live story-telling and spoken word pieces, to those in more visual mediums such as documentary and experimental film, graphic life narratives and comics, photographic representations and multi-media installations, vocal musical genres including Middle Eastern rap/hip-hop, as well as movement and dance (including works by and/or about Raja Shehadeh, Diana Abu Jaber, Assia Djebar, Sayyed Kashua, Ari Folman, Leila Abdul Razzaq, Sama al-Shaibi, DAM/Tamer Nafer, Shadia Mansour, Larissa Sansour, and others).
subject: ENGLISH
sub_title: - Connecting Life Stories, Connecting Lives: The Middle East and Beyond
advisory_prerequisites: Enrollment restricted to first-year students, including those with sophomore standing.
repeatability: May not be repeated for credit.

title: The Art of the Story
description: Humans have been called story-telling animals. Indeed, from our earliest entrance into the language as young children, we have all been enthralled, inspired, and instructed by stories. And for good reason: narrative forms provide us with potent and versatile tools for ordering and preserving our often unruly experience of the world. In Art of the Story, we explore the cognitive and developmental foundations of our collective addiction to narrative and its role not only in the evolution of literary genres but also in the practice of professions from journalism, health, and law to business and public policy.
subject: ENGLISH
repeatability: May not be repeated for credit.

title: Introduction to Language and Rhetoric
description: Trolling. Disinformation campaigns. Ad hominem attacks. Gaslighting. Obfuscation and pedantry. These things, and more, are modes of address that have come to typify popular representations of social media discourse. In this class, we’ll examine the theory and practice of bullshit as it relates to digital rhetoric and online circulation. Among other questions, we’ll consider how and where manipulation, truth, and ethos mediate what we popularly describe or understand as bullshit. We’ll think together about how complex appeals to lived experience and alternative data circulate among certain communities of practice online, with particular attention paid to anti-vaccination discourse. We’ll not only examine what it means to argue on the interwebs, but we’ll also ask what it means to imagine digital rhetorical practices that center on questions of ethics, justice, and power.
subject: ENGLISH
repeatability: May be repeated for a maximum of 8 credit(s).

title: Introduction to Women and Literature
description: In this class, we’ll examine women rhetors who challenged and complicated rhetorical conventions in order to make their voices heard. In addition to organized social movements such as abolition, suffrage, labor, and equal rights, we’ll also consider less-formal channels through which women have engaged the public sphere, such as music, journalism, and digital activism. Throughout we will pay close attention to how women have used language to effect social change. We will also pay close attention to issues that have both united and divided women, especially along lines of race, class, and culture.
subject: ENGLISH
repeatability: May not be repeated for credit.

title: Introduction to Disability Studies
description: What is disability justice? How is disability justice inextricable from racial justice, class justice, gender justice, and justice for LGBTQ+ people?  How do we imagine and enact disability justice in the world, which necessarily encompasses online “spaces” and digital tools and platforms? These are some of the questions that will guide us throughout the semester.
subject: ENGLISH
repeatability: May not be repeated for credit.

title: Literature and Writing Outside the Classroom
subject: ENGLISH
repeatability: May be elected twice for credit.  May be elected more than once in the same term.

title: Literature and Writing Outside the Classroom
description: In a time when we've been socially distanced, this course asks us to write letters--good-old-fashioned ink on paper folded into a licked, stamped envelope dropped into a mailbox. Two primary goals motivate our production of letters. Our first goal is to use letter correspondence to create new channels for dialogue. To whom do you want to write? What will you say to them? What will you ask? What insights and visions will they send back? Our second goal is to use the epistolary form to explore questions of genre, media, and craft. How is a letter different than, say, a text? What makes some letters more evocative than others? How does this kind of writing connect to the writing we do in the other parts of our lives? What can this form help us to say? And how do our letters represent us, our essential selves? The hope is that we can come to see the letter as a useful tool for expressing ourselves in new (or is it old?) ways.
subject: ENGLISH
repeatability: May be elected twice for credit.  May be elected more than once in the same term.

title: Creative Writing
description: “In this section of English 223, we will read fiction, poetry, creative non-fiction, articles, back of cereal boxes, Wu-Tang lyrics, and much more; though the emphasis will be on poetry and fiction.
subject: ENGLISH
repeatability: May not be repeated for credit.

title: Creative Writing
description: English 223 introduces students to the craft and critique that characterize creative writing, both as a discipline in the English Department at the University of Michigan and as a profession. This course treats creative writing as a skill and a habit of mind that students can actively develop through disciplined practice. The course also encourages students to participate in the writerly community as literary citizens. In addition to doing copious writing, students read published work in multiple genres, attend local readings, and respond to one another’s creative work. Over the course of the term, students produce writing that demonstrates both deliberate attention to craft and reflective awareness of their own and others’ creative processes. English 223 prepares students for upper-level creative writing courses in fiction and poetry and is required for both the sub-concentration and the minor in Creative Writing.
subject: ENGLISH
repeatability: May not be repeated for credit.

title: Academic Argumentation
description: All sections of ENGLISH 225 focus on examining and employing effective academic argumentation. Academic argumentation refers to the presentation, explanation, and assessment of claims through written reasoning that utilizes appropriate evidence and writing conventions. The course builds on and refines skills from introductory writing ENGLISH 124 and 125 courses, as well as providing a basic introduction to finding and effectively incorporating research into student writing for use in a range of future academic contexts.
subject: ENGLISH
advisory_prerequisites: Completion of the First-Year Writing Requirement.
repeatability: May not be repeated for credit.

title: Academic Argumentation
description: All sections of ENGLISH 225 focus on examining and employing effective academic argumentation. Academic argumentation refers to the presentation, explanation, and assessment of claims through written reasoning that utilizes appropriate evidence and writing conventions. The course builds on and refines skills from introductory writing ENGLISH 124 and 125 courses, as well as providing a basic introduction to finding and effectively incorporating research into student writing for use in a range of future academic contexts.
subject: ENGLISH
advisory_prerequisites: Completion of the First-Year Writing Requirement.
repeatability: May not be repeated for credit.

title: Academic Argumentation
description: All sections of ENGLISH 225 focus on examining and employing effective academic argumentation. Academic argumentation refers to the presentation, explanation, and assessment of claims through written reasoning that utilizes appropriate evidence and writing conventions. The course builds on and refines skills from introductory writing ENGLISH 124 and 125 courses, as well as providing a basic introduction to finding and effectively incorporating research into student writing for use in a range of future academic contexts.
subject: ENGLISH
advisory_prerequisites: Completion of the First-Year Writing Requirement.
repeatability: May not be repeated for credit.

Academic argumentation refers to the presentation, explanation, and assessment of claims through written reasoning that utilizes appropriate evidence and writing conventions. The course builds on and refines skills from introductory writing ENGLISH 124 and 125 courses, as well as providing a basic introduction to finding and effectively incorporating research into student writing for use in a range of future academic contexts.
subject: ENGLISH
advisory_prerequisites: Completion of the First-Year Writing Requirement.
